title: Markets trim losses after US creates 209,000 job in July - business live | Business | The Guardian
summary: european markets close down for second day .
us judge accuses argentina of half-truths .
nine reasons why india 's wto veto shocked the world .
markets reeling as july came to a close .

documents.title: european markets close down for second day
text: investors were shunning shares ahead of the weekend , and although markets came off their worst levels they still fell for the second day .

a combination of concerns was behind the declines , from argentina 's default , the sanctions on russia , the violence in gaza and the state of eurozone banks after the huge losses at espirito santo revealed this week .
the other major factor was the prospect of us interest rates rising more quickly than expected , following better than expected gdp figures and a hawkish outlook from fed member charles prosser .
but the weaker than forecast us non-farm payroll numbers ( coverage from here ) took some of the steam out of that market fear .

even so it was another down day : the ftse 100 finished 50.93 points or 0.76 % lower germany 's dax dropped 2.1 % to 9210.08 france 's cac closed 1.02 % lower at 4202.78 italy 's ftse mib ended 1.01 % down at 20,362.41 spain 's ibex fell 1.8 % to 10 , 514 argentina 's merval is currently down 2.8 % on wall street the dow jones industrial average is 106 points or 0.64 % lower .
and on that note , it 's time to close up for the evening .
thanks for all your comments , and we 'll be back on monday .

documents.title: us judge accuses argentina of half-truths
text: fresh news is coming out of the us on argentina 's debt default this week .

in a court hearing , the judge at the centre of argentina 's legal battle with so-called holdout bondholders - which it calls vulture funds '' - has accused the south american country of releasing misleading information '' .
us judge , thomas griesa , criticised argentina for telling what he called half truths '' by saying it had met debt obligations .
to recap , argentina technically defaulted on its debt obligations for the second time in 13 years this week after last-minute talks with creditors in new york failed to reach a deal .
the country has been locked in a decade-long dispute with hold-out investors - a group of us hedge funds led by billionaire paul singer 's nml capital , an affiliate of elliott management .

the vast majority of argentina 's bondholders agreed to debt restructuring deals in 2005 and 2010 following its 2001 default , wiping off more than 70 % of the value of their investment but securing regular interest payments .
but the holdout investors refused the restructuring and are demanding repayment in full .
griesa has ruled argentina can not pay its other creditors their interest payments without also paying the holdouts more than $ 1.5bn .
argentina says it has not actually defaulted because it tried to pay the latest interest instalment due to the majority of its creditors .
it deposited $ 539m ( £ 319m ) due to holders of restructured bonds on 30 june but the move was blocked , however , by griesa .
today he said a settlement was the only was to resolve the case .
reuters reports from the hearing in new york , the griesa said : nothing that has happened this week has removed the necessity of working out a settlement . ''
he is also quoted as saying : the republic has issued public statements that have been highly misleading , and that has to be stopped . ''
and half-truths are not the same as the truth . ''
argentina 's lawyer jonathan blackman , meanwhile says the country is committed to a dialogue and agrees with the court that a settlement is the only way to resolve '' the dispute .
separately , the international swaps and derivatives association ( isda ) effectively declared argentina in default .
back to the uk and the debate around when interest rates will start to rise after their long stretch at record low 0.5 % .
people 's expectations for inflation over the next year , watched closely by bank of england policymakers , have edged up slightly , according to a poll .
inflation expectations for the next 12 months were up to 2.2 % in july , from 2.1 % in june , according to a monthly yougov survey .
inflation expectations for the next five to 10 years were unchanged at 3 % in july .

reuters reports : while the medians are little changed , expectations that inflation will be positive but low are becoming more widespread , '' said michael saunders , chief uk economist at citi , which sponsors the poll .
fewer people expect no inflation , falling prices or relatively high inflation .
all of this is benign from the ( bank of england 's ) point of view . ''
the bank 's rate-setting monetary policy committee ( mpc ) meets next week and economists expect no change in policy for now .
but with the recovery seemingly becoming more entrenched , markets are pricing in the first rate hike by the turn of the year .
the latest official numbers on inflation showed it at a five-month high of 1.9 % in june , just below the bank 's government-set target of 2.0 % on the consumer price index ( cpi ) measure .
those ism numbers from the us follow a separate report for the uk showing its manufacturers suffered a slowdown , with activity rising at the slowest pace in a year in july .
surveys in the eurozone also painted a worsening there .
in the us the headline activity reading beat expectations with support from jobs and from new orders .
the report 's employment component jumped to 58.2 in july from 52.8 in june , hitting its highest since june 2011 .
new orders rose to 63.4 from 58.9 .
a reading above 50 shows expansion .
reacting to the report , james knightley , economist at ing financial markets said it brings some welcome cheer after today 's earlier non-farm payrolls report missed expectations .

he comments : after that pretty poor employment report we have actually got a very robust ism manufacturing index interestingly , the employment component surged to 58.2 from 52.8 , taking it to its highest level since june 2011 , contradicting today 's softish jobs numbers .
production is up while new orders jumped nearly 5 points to 63.4 .
this is all really good news for the us growth story with the headline ism index at levels historically consistent with gdp growth running at 4 % year-on-year versus the current rate of 2.4 % .

it also backs up our positive assessment on the us economy and our view that the labour market will continue to strengthen , inflation pressures will build , the dollar will rally a lot further and the fed will tighten earlier than the market currently anticipates .

documents.title: us manufacturing up pace
text: the us is the latest country to report manufacturing data this afternoon and numbers from the world 's biggest economy have topped expectations .
the us manufacturing sector expanded at its fastest pace in more than three years in july , according to the institute for supply management .
its index of factory activity rose to 57.1 from 55.3 in june .
that was the highest since april 2011 and beat the consensus forecast for a reading of 56.0 in a reuters poll of economists .
more details and reaction to follow
markets are peculiar things .
although the jobs data came in worse than expected , us stock futures have pared their losses , while us treasury yields have fallen .
this is because investors are more hopeful that the federal reserve will keep interest rates low for longer .

the ftse100 has recovered some earlier losses , but remains 0.92 % ( 6668 points ) down on the day pedro da costa ( @ pdacosta ) the market is pleased there were n't 'too many ' jobs created - cnbc punditry
the guardian 's story : us adds 209,000 jobs in july as unemployment rate rises to 6.2 %
more reaction on us non-farm payrolls james knightley at ing bank sounds underwhelmed , but thinks the outlook for the labour market is improving .
the us labour report for july is a bit disappointing really .
payrolls rose 209,000 and there were a net 15,000 upward revisions , but this is still a bit softer than the 230,000 consensus .
there was worse news on the unemployment rate front .

it actually rose to 6.2 % from 6.1 % - the market was looking for it to stay at 6.1 % , but we were thinking a sub-6 % figure was possible all in all we got today 's report wrong , but we are still very comfortable with our view that labour market slack is shrinking and the improving growth outlook will keep that trend in place .
as the pool of available labour continues to shrink we will see wages respond positively and inflation pressures within the economy will build .
consequently , we look for the federal reserve 's commentary to gradually shift in the months ahead and favour an early 2q15 rate hike .
angus campbell , senior analyst at fxpro , says that investors are expecting interest rates to rise sooner than they thought .
the labour market in the us is improving as can be seen on a weekly basis , as well as the monthly nonfarm payrolls .

despite today 's hiccup in average earnings , thursday 's employment cost index was higher than expected , setting off a few alarm bells at the fed and this will all translate into a stronger us economy .

this week concludes with investors becoming more fractious , not only due to rising geopolitical tensions , but because of the realisation that interest rates are likely to rise sooner than many had previously thought .
both equity and fx volatility has spiked dramatically in the past few days and equity markets in particular have been hit hard .
the dollar strength that established itself in july has continued into august , for sterling and the euro , their dizzy highs against the dollar only a few weeks ago seem a long way off now .
gbpusd in particular looks like it 's fallen off a cliff since mid-july .
average earnings showed 2 % annual growth , below expectations .
tanweer akram , senior economist at voya investment management , thinks that the federal reserve 's open markets committee is likely to scale back its asset purchase programme at a measured '' pace .

though slack remains in the u.s. labor market and mostly low valued added and low paying jobs are being created , labor market indicators , such as the hires rate and job openings rate , are gradually improving however the pace of economic growth in the first half of the year has been disappointing with housing activity showing limited progress .
here is a round-up of the best instant reaction to the us jobs data justin wolfers ( @ justinwolfers ) all told , this is pretty much the payrolls report most were expecting .
it 's not through-the-roof exciting , but the recovery continues .
shaun richards ( @ notayesmansecon ) us bls : in july , average hourly earnings for all employees on private nonfarm payrolls edged up by 1 cent to $ 24.45 .
# nfp not much !
it 's time to get out the data charts and dust off the superlatives .
jamie mcgeever ( @ reutersjamie ) that 's now 46 consecutive months of us job creation , the 2nd longest run since world war two and only 3 months from a new record .
pedro da costa ( @ pdacosta ) this employment report marks the first six-month period of above-200,000/month jobs reading since 1997 .

and my personal favourite justin wolfers ( @ justinwolfers ) it 's a bore-the-pants-off-you , the economy-is-doing-what-it-should-be sort of reports w/ a slight edge of weakness the media will overstate .
participation in the workforce ticked up to 62.9 % , from 62.8 % in june .
the us jobless rate was 6.2 % in july , slightly off expectations .

documents.title: us added jobs in 209,000 jobs
text: breaking news : the us gained 209,000 non-farm jobs in july , lower than expectations of 233,000 .
but june 's figure was revised up : statisticians now say that the us created 298,000 non-farm jobs in june , against a previous estimate of 288,000 .
hot off the wires : france 's prime minister manuel valls has warned that the eurozone faces a real risk of deflation .
and with the country about to pack up and go on holiday , he also warned that france would face a difficult economic situation in the autumn .

i 'll add more when i get it , but meantime here are some highlights from reuters ' politics and economics correspondent in paris nicholas vinocur ( @ nicholasvinocur ) asked whether france to admit wo n't reach 3-percent gdp-deficit ratio by 2015 , valls says : `` we have to wait for the data '' sometime in mid-aug nicholas vinocur ( @ nicholasvinocur ) french pm valls now : `` france got bogged down because it did n't reform .
it 's my responsibility to conduct the reforms our country needs . ''
the speech is n't impressing everyone .
yannis koutsomitis ( @ yannikouts ) french pm valls : `` # ecb is powerless to fight against strong # euro '' .
too much champagne for breakfast manuel ?
hello , jennifer rankin taking over while we await the us jobs data .
and here is a tasty lunchtime story .
waitrose has warned that the free coffees and newspapers it hands out to customers will cut its profits .
the upmarket grocer , the uk 's sixth largest supermarket , has been gaining market share , but now discounter aldi is snapping at its heels in the supermarket pecking order .
the ft has a good take on the story .

mark price , waitrose 's managing director , said the supermarket had put substantial investment into its loyalty card programme , which allows customers free tea and coffee and a newspaper if they spend more than £ 5 .
as you know , we are in a period of unprecedented investment and this will have an impact on the profit we report next month .
the scheme has been popular , but supposedly criticised by some customers , who think it attracts the wrong kind of shopper .
even david cameron weighed into the debate earlier this year , after labour accused it of damaging the interests of independent traders .
so these are the big issues of british politics : bacon sandwiches and freebie coffees

documents.title: lunchtime round-up
text: it 's midday - time for another look at the markets and a round-up of today 's main news .
financial markets have started august in the red amid worries over the global economy , interest rate hikes , argentina , ukraine and gaza .
the ftse 100 index in london is down nearly 100 points at 6633.60 , a 1.4 % fall .
germany 's dax has lost just over 2 % and france 's cac is off 1.4 % .
at 1.30pm , we will get us non-farm payrolls , which are expected to show some 230,000 new jobs were created in the economy in july , down from june 's strong number of 288,000 .
people will be watching the earnings figures for any signs of a in inflation , as this is crucial to the interest rate outlook with the fed getting more concerned about rising inflation .

india has blocked a landmark global trade deal , which could prove fatal for the world trade organisation uk and eurozone manufacturing growth disappointed in july amid rising tensions in ukraine the isda trade body will rule at 4pm bst whether argentina 's default is a 'credit event .
us judge thomas griesa , who has been hearing the case , has called a meeting at the same time to discuss argentina 's recent default ''

documents.title: wto at critical juncture
text: the world trade organisation has reached its make or break moment , writes our economics correspondent larry elliott .
obituaries for the world trade organisation have been prepared many times over the past decade but proved premature .
this time they may be needed .

make no mistake , the failure of the wto 's members to ratify a deal designed to streamline customs ' procedures by preventing needless delays and corruption at borders is a massive setback to the multilateral trading system .
it paves the way for countries to cut their own bilateral or regional deals .
for the wto , it threatens to be fatal .

documents.title: nine reasons why india 's wto veto shocked the world
text: returning to our earlier to the breakdown of the world trade talks , reuters has compiled a list of nine reasons why india 's decision to block a landmark deal shocked the world .
its refusal to sign the agreement drawn up last december in bali to streamline global customs procedures is a serious blow to the world trade organisation , which was set up 19 years ago .
trade diplomats in geneva have said they are flabbergasted '' , astonished '' and dismayed '' and described india 's position as hostage-taking '' and suicidal '' .
having read up on it , i 'm baffled .
click here for more delegates arrive for a meeting at the world trade organisation ( wto ) headquarters in geneva on 31 july .
coffrini/afp/getty images

in corporate news , royal bank of scotland warned this morning that profits could by hit by the ongoing investigation into potential manipulation of the foreign exchange markets , our banking correspondent jill treanor reports .
you can read the full story here .

in 17 pages of legal disclosures attached to its first-half results , the 81 % taxpayer-owned bank revealed the cost of fines or settlements that could come with the wide-ranging inquiry could be material '' .

the bank issued its results last friday - a week earlier than expected - after an improvement in bad debts drove profits to their highest levels since the bailout in 2008.as the edinburgh-based bank confirmed the rise in profits to £ 2.6bn , it published information about its performance in the first half of the year along with details about the risks and litigation it could face .
but it did not take any additional provisions for the potential cost .

artificial hips-and-knees maker smith & nephew - europe 's largest maker of artificial joints - said it would offer americans a new no frills '' service that will slash the cost of buying its replacement hips and knees .
chief executive olivier bohuon said the new syncera service should appeal to 5-10 % of us hospitals that can not afford its full service .
by stripping out some traditional costs , such as sending a company technician to attend surgery , he said overall costs could be slashed by 40-50 % .
the company shrugged off problems in its wound management division to post a 10 % rise in group trading profits to $ 255m in the second quarter , an improvement after a weak start to the year .
a colored x-ray of the pelvis and the hips showing an artificial hip joint .
/corbis

documents.title: markets reeling as july came to a close
text: july trading ended on a sour note , observes daniel sugarman , market strategist at etx capital .

markets plunged worldwide as argentina 's debt default , russian tension , portuguese banking fears and a highly negative chicago purchasing managers index reading ( 52.6 ) all came together in an unholy mix , with markets giving up all gains made over the course of the month - and in some cases , in the course of the whole year so far .
an example of the latter was the dow , which fell by 317 points ( 1.88 % ) over the course of the day 's trading .
the s & p was down by 2 % while the nasdaq was down 2.1 % .
the effects rolled across to asian markets , with the nikkei down by 0.63 % , the hang seng down by 0.91 % and the shanghai composite down 0.74 % .
european markets are also feeling the pinch this morning .

us non-farm payroll figures are out later today and markets will be hanging onto the results , with good numbers having the potential to help markets rally somewhat whilst bad numbers might herald an even greater fall .
more reaction to the uk manufacturing slowdown .

david richardson , head of manufacturing at lloyds bank commercial banking , mid markets , said : while some of the forward momentum has slowed , the overall performance of the manufacturing sector so far this year has been positive .
the country 's makers have offered a robust source of job creation and export activity , in the face of a strengthening sterling .

for us , it has been pleasing to see our manufacturing customers invest in state-of-the-art plant and machinery , drive efficiencies and fund cutting-edge r & d , which are all critical to the development of a high value manufacturing economy .
jeremy cook , chief economist at the currency company world first said : manufacturing growth in the uk remains at a solid but not spectacular level into q3 of this year .
while overall output has remained strong , the speed and pace of improvement has started to slow .
the key figure for wider-economy watchers is that the rate of manufacturing job creation has slipped to its lowest rate in 9 months .

the large falls in the jobless rate has been the stick with which the bank of england has been beaten up with in a bid to get them to raise interest rates this year ; a softening of that pressure in jobs markets will help the bank of england maintain its current poise .

lee hopley , chief economist at eef , the manufacturers ' organisation , said : the bottom line from this figure is that the relatively rapid acceleration in growth seen in the first half of 2014 will ebb over the second half of the year .

the lower reading than previously should n't set off any alarm bells as the indicator is still consistent with a decent pace of growth across the sector and , continued prospects for more job creation .
the survey also points to companies benefiting from new product developments and efforts to sell into emerging markets .

nevertheless the patchy industrial performance across europe , initial signs of some cost pressures emerging and , capacity issues in the supply chain could yet weigh on the sector in the coming months .

documents.title: european stock markets slide after disappointing manufacturing data , ahead of us non-farm payrolls
text: the ftse was down 80 points when the manufacturing survey data came out , and is now trading nearly 70 points lower at 660.44 , a 1 % fall .
germany 's dax has lost 1.7 % and france 's cac is 1.2 % lower .
markit said manufacturing growth remains strong by historical standards and the slowdown is in line with the bank of england 's forecast that the economic recovery will slow a tad in coming months .
but the drop may also reflect uncertainty about the worsening crisis in ukraine .
growth in new factory orders hit a four-month low .

rob dobson , senior economist at markit , said : it remains too early to gauge the impact of the ukraine crisis , but the worry is that the combined effects of expected policy tightening , heightened economic uncertainty and sluggish trade could mean manufacturing growth could suddenly weaken more than expected .

markit economics ( @ markiteconomics ) strong uk mfg growth continues in july but headline # pmi falls slightly to 55.4 ( 57.2 in june ) many city economists expect the bank of england to hike interest rates around the turn of the year .
here 's some instant reaction to the uk factory data from james knightley , uk economist at ing in london .
the uk manufacturing pmi survey has dropped from 57.2 to 55.4 in july , weaker than the 57.2 consensus .
this suggests that the sector is expanding at its slowest rate in 12 months .
it is a little disappointing , but it remains at historically high levels and still points to an acceleration in official manufacturing output growth , which is due for release next week .

it is possible that concerns over potential bank of england interest rate rises are weighing a little , as they clearly were on this week 's consumer confidence number , while the ukraine situation may also be making firms a little nervous about expanding output .
sterling strength could also be something of an issue too .
nonetheless , it is important to remember that this index is still firmly in expansion territory and that the slack in the economy continues to be eroded .

furthermore , upward gdp revisions due in late september are likely to indicate that the amount of spare capacity is smaller than previously thought and so we are comfortable with our november boe rate hike prediction .

documents.title: uk manufacturing growth unexpectedly slows to lowest rate in a year
text: big miss : british manufacturing grew at the slowest pace in a year in july , the markit/cips survey showed .
the purchasing managers ' index for july dropped to 55.4 from 57.2 in june - its lowest level since july 2013 and well below what economists were expecting .

documents.title: eurozone manufacturing growth disappoints amid ukraine tensions
text: overall eurozone manufacturing growth failed to up as expected last month amid the worsening stand-off between ukraine and russia .
markit 's final july manufacturing pmi held steady at 51.8 but was slightly below an earlier flash estimate of 51.9 .
a sub-index measuring output alone dipped to 52.7 from june 's 52.8 .
chris williamson , chief economist at markit , said : the situation in the eurozone has clearly worsened from the promising signs of economic revival seen earlier in the year .
he said the final reading was lower than the flash estimate most likely reflecting growing concerns following the escalation of the crisis in ukraine towards the end of the month .
price pressures in factories across the eurozone remain muted .
the output price gauge , which measures the prices charged by manufacturers , fell to 50.1 from 50.4 .

documents.title: eurozone manufacturing surveys paint worsening
text: the eurozone purchasing managers ' surveys are also out this morning .
here 's a quick round-up .
germany 's index has come in at 52.4 , slightly worse than expected ( 52.9 ) , but it 's an improvement on june .
in france , factory activity worsened with the pmi falling to 47.8 , a seven-month low , from 48.2 in june .
the italian manufacturing index dropped to an eight-month low .
in spain , the index has slipped slightly to 53.9 from 54.6 , but remains pretty strong .
anything above 50 indicates expansion in the sector ; anything below points to contraction .
edward hugh ( @ edward hugh ) spain july manufacturing pmi slipped back slightly to 53.9 from 54.6 .
still quite strong momentum .
jeroen blokland ( @ jsblokland ) # france # pmi , better than expected but still pretty 'terrible '
european stock markets have fallen back further ahead of the us jobs numbers this afternoon .
the ftse 100 index in london has lost nearly 45 points , or 0.6 % , to 6687.45 while germany 's dax and france 's cac are off nearly 1 % .

here in the uk , after a few quiet days the main focus today will be on july 's manufacturing pmi at 9.30am bst , which will provide an update on business conditions at the start of the third quarter .
economists at daiwa say expectations are for a modest drop in the headline index , although at 57.2 it will continue to point to robust expansion .
inflationary pressures in the eurozone are also rising , suggesting efforts by the european central bank to fight deflation are working .
they have reached a 27-month high , according to the eurozone future inflation gauge , which is published by the economic cycle research institute .
it rose to 96.7 in june from 96.2 in april .
according to official figures released on thursday , annual inflation in the eurozone dropped to just 0.4 % in july , the lowest since the height of the financial crisis in 2009 .

documents.title: wages in focus in us non-farm payrolls report
text: hewson at cmc markets uk believes wages could be interesting in today 's us non-farm payrolls report , given policymakers ' increasing concerns over inflation .
the numbers are out at 1.30pm bst .
expectations are for a number of around 232k , but given this week 's slightly disappointing adp number , it could come in lower .

even if its lower than that as long as the number does n't fall below 200k , markets are likely to be fairly relaxed about it , with the us dollar likely to remain strong as it enjoys its best monthly performance in over a year , against a basket of currencies .
a strong number will also make it harder for the fed to argue that there is still a significant amount of slack in the economy , with the unemployment rate set to remain unchanged at 6.1 % .

as for inflation there has been an awful lot of chatter about the employment cost index which showed a sharp rise of 0.7 % in q2 , and is a gauge that reflects how much companies , governments and non-profit institutions pay their employees in wages and benefits .

if today 's average hourly earnings data for july shows similar price pressures building up , we could well see further losses on stock markets and further us dollar gains , as investors start to worry about the inflation bogeyman .
expectations are for rise to 2.2 % year on year .

documents.title: us non-farm payrolls forecast to rise by 230,000
text: it 's us non-farm payrolls day .
economists are expecting another chunky increase in the number of jobs created in the economy in july , albeit down from june 's strong 288,000 number .
economists at daiwa say : following a bad day for us equity markets yesterday , today 's numerous us releases should make for at least mildly encouraging reading about the outlook for the economy .
the most noteworthy figures come from the latest labour market report .
non-farm payrolls are expected to have risen by 230k in july - a good deal weaker than june 's 288k , but still well in excess of the average over the past year .

meanwhile , the unemployment rate is expected to have remained unchanged at the near-six-year low of 6.1 % , not least due to the strengthening in the labour market drawing more workers into the labour force .

today also brings the manufacturing ism , which is expected to indicate a slight further improvement in business conditions at the start of q3 , though a moderate pace of activity in the manufacturing sector should still hold the measure close to the readings in the prior two months .
personal income and spending numbers for june and vehicle sales figures for july are also slated for publication .

documents.title: asian stock markets dip but losses limited by healthy chinese numbers
text: most asian stock markets dipped overnight after the sell-off on wall street .
japan 's nikkei dropped 0.6 % to 15,528.72 and hong kong 's hang seng shed 0.5 % to 24,623.81 .
however losses were less severe than in the us as investors took some hope from upbeat reports on china 's economy .
monthly surveys of manufacturing in china suggested that the economy - the world 's second-largest - is responding well to recent mini-stimulus measures .

the official purchasing managers ' index measuring activity in china 's factories reached its highest level in 27 months , while a similar report from hsbc showed the fastest rate of improvement in a year and a half .

documents.title: wall street sell-off on disappointing earnings and expectations of fed rate hike
text: all major stock markets fell on thursday , and european markets are down again this morning .
in london , the ftse 100 index is off nearly 28 points , or 0.4 % , at 6702.71 .
michael hewson , chief market analyst at cmc markets uk , reckons the slide in markets has little to do with argentina 's woes , and more with the interest rate outlook for the us .

a much more probable explanation is likely to be found much closer to home in the prospect that a fed rate hike is probably nearer than markets had initially thought at the beginning of the week , or the month of july for that matter , due to concerns that the fed is underestimating inflation .

throw in concerns about the strength of the global economy , china , europe , the knock on effects of russian sanctions , and any countermeasures , which could well spill over onto the strength of company earnings , along with the effect falling prices will have on debt to gdp ratios , and i think you 'll find you 've got a pretty good reason to maybe start taking some money off the table .
the dow jones industrial average lost more than 300 points and closed down 1.9 % at 16,563.30 , its worst one-day drop since february .
the s & p 500 shed 2 % to 1,930.67 , its biggest drop since april , and the nasdaq fell 2.1 % to 4,369.77 amid disappointing corporate earnings reports .
argentina defaulted on its debt for the second time in 13 years on thursday , sending the country 's stock market tumbling nearly 7 % while the peso lost more than 4 % against the dollar .

there are two important events today : the international swaps and derivatives association will rule on whether argentina 's failure to repay its debts before wednesday night 's deadline is a credit event '' - which could trigger credit default swaps ( insurance on the bonds ) us judge thomas griesa , who has been hearing the case , has called a meeting for 11am est in new york ( 4pm bst ) to discuss argentina 's recent default '' joseph cotterill ( @ jsphctrl ) bring popcorn .

documents.title: failure to reach deal puts wto 'on very uncertain ground '
text: azevedo asked wto members to reflect long and hard on the ramifications of this setback . ''
meanwhile , the us ambassador to the wto , michael punke , said the failure to reach a deal had put this institution on very uncertain new ground '' .
india , for its part , said last year that the agreement could jeopardise its policies to feed its poor .
there had been a last-ditch effort by us officials to try and persuade india to agree to a compromise that would have secured a world trade deal .
the wto reached an agreement in december in bali to standardise customs procedures , and the deadline to ratify that deal was thursday .
india refused to sign without a a parallel agreement giving developing countries more leeway to subsidise and stockpile food .
some economists estimate that the bali agreement could save wto members more than $ 1 trillion , and create 21m jobs , 18m of them in developing countries .
wto director general roberto azevedo said : i do not have the necessary elements that would lead to me to conclude that a breakthrough is possible .
we got closer
good morning , and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets , the world economy , business and the eurozone .
we 've woken up to news that the world trade organisation 's 160 members have failed to ratify an agreement designed to streamline the global trade system .
it would have been the first comprehensive global trade agreement since the organisation was set up in 1995 .

key_events.text:
6.05pm BST
18:05
European markets close down for second day
